metadata.case_name: Jabalpur Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Sambhu Prasad Srivastava

facts.text: Appellant is a company incorporated under Indian Companies Act, registered office at 12 Mission Row Calcutta, engaged in generation and distribution of electricity at Jabalpur.
Jabalpur office in charge of Resident Engineer Mr. Leonard Shell Macleod.
Power of attorney dated June 26 1957 by company to Mr. Macleod, clause 10: subject to Standing Orders, to appoint dismiss suspend or terminate services of employees at Jabalpur.
November 12 1957: Charge sheet served on respondent Sambhu Prasad Srivastava by Mr. Macleod alleging substitution of 13 companyls of V.I.R. cable in stores with local market cable.
Srivastava's reply: shortage noticed on eve of audit, remonstrated with subordinates, acted in best interests of company, no dishonest intention.

January 16 1958: Resident Engineer issued discharge letter referencing charge sheet and investigations, interview with Chief Engineer J.W. Fawcett on January 15, company does not find it possible to retain services, discharged with immediate effect.

Srivastava applied to Assistant Labour Commissioner Jabalpur alleging contravention of C.P. Berar Industrial Tribunal Settlement Act and Standing Orders; powers only by Managing Director; order is dismissal not discharge; cls.14 18 19 20 violated.
Company reply: Resident Engineer had power under PoA to hold enquiry and take disciplinary action, action amounts to company's action, no violation of Standing Orders.
September 10 1958: Assistant Labour Commissioner ordered reinstatement without break in service but without back wages.
State Industrial Court: order of discharge is in substance dismissal, misconduct not proved, Resident Engineer not empowered; refused to interfere, rejected both revisional applications.
Both parties moved Madhya Pradesh High Court under Art. 226.

High Court May 15 1959: powers under cl.19 not delegable to RE; cl.20 reserved to company not covered by PoA cl.10; order not under cl.20; refused to interfere with reinstatement, dismissed company's app; allowed employee's app ordering back wages.

Standing Orders: cl.18 misconduct includes theft fraud dishonesty; cl.19 penalties including summary dismissal without notice/compensation after procedure; cl.20 general right to discharge for loss of confidence; cl.21 notice of censure.

legal_issues.text: When under the Standing Orders of a Company the Company is empowered to take disciplinary action against an employee by proceeding in the prescribed manner can that power be legally delegated by the Company to any of its officers?
Whether the order dated January 16 1958 was made under cl.19 or cl.20 of the Standing Orders.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under power of attorney the Resident Engineer had power to hold enquiry and take disciplinary action; action by him is action by Company.
Provisions of Standing Orders not violated.

respondent_arguments.text: Order contravenes C.P. Berar Industrial Tribunal Settlement Act and Standing Orders; powers under Standing Orders exercisable only by Managing Director.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Standing Orders cls.14 18 19 20; C.P. Berar Industrial Tribunal Settlement Act

respondent_arguments.text: Order though in form of discharge was really dismissal.
Resident Engineer not competent to take action under cl.20 as it empowers Company only.

court_reasoning.text: Order of January 16 1958 is under cl.20 (discharge for loss of confidence) not cl.19 (dismissal for misconduct), as it does not find employee guilty, references investigations and interview, no mention of guilt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Employer acted fairly and generously under cl.20.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.20 empowers Company but RE acted under PoA cl.10 which covers powers to dismiss suspend terminate subject to Standing Orders; delegation valid as company acts through officers per Articles of Association and exigencies of business.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No legal bar to delegation; PoA cl.10 words 'subject to Standing Orders' mean delegate cannot exceed company's powers under them, not that cannot exercise at all.

court_reasoning.text: Resident Engineer's action under cl.20 via PoA amounts to company's action.

holdings.text: Order of discharge by Resident Engineer validly made under delegated power via PoA cl.10 exercising company's power under Standing Orders cl.20.
Order is discharge under cl.20 not dismissal under cl.19.

statutes_cited.name: Standing Orders
statutes_cited.relevance: Govern misconduct penalties, procedure for dismissal/suspension, general right to discharge for loss of confidence; powers delegable subject to PoA.

statutes_cited.name: C. P. Berar Industrial Tribunal Settlement Act

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; orders of High Court, State Industrial Court and Assistant Labour Commissioner set aside; company's application under Art.226 to stand disposed of.

key_quotes.text: "When under the Standing Orders of a Company the Company is empowered to take disciplinary action against an employee by proceeding in the prescribed manner can that power be legally delegated by the Company to any of its officers? That is the principal question raised in this appeal."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The only reasonable view to take of this order... is that this order was being made under cl. 20 on the ground that the employer had lost confidence in the employee and was in fact and in law an order of discharge as distinct from an order of dismissal or suspension."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "We therefore hold, disagreeing with the High Court, and the Courts below that the order of discharge made by the Resident Engineer was in exercise of the power validly delegated to him and that there has been no breach of the Standing Orders by such action."
key_quotes.speaker: court
